context_01: Swera is asking you for advice on how to be successful in life. She of course would rather have a life of leisure, but she’s willing to work hard if that’s what she needs to do to succeed. Of course, the odds of success are a lot higher if you work hard than if you sit around doing nothing. So you tell her:
stanza:
# wamábug’ uti kúmbé íwabya mundu omo-maísha wawú, wángayitsing’ okomubíri
u-a-ma-bug-a u-ti kumbe i-u-a-bi-a mundu omo-maisha wawu, u-anga-yitsing-a o-ko-mubiri
SM.2sg-TM-TM-say-FV SM.2sg-C better.that C-SM.2sg-TM-be-FV c1.person AUG-c18-life 2sg.POSS, SM.2sg-MOD-persevere-FV AUG-c17-work
Intended: "if you want to succeed, you should work hard"

"If you want to succeed, you should work hard."

context_13: Some celebrities published a list of “1,000 books that everyone should read before they die”. Since then, Swera has been reading the books on that list, and only those books. She intends to read every single book on that list whenever she can get her hands on a copy, but she refuses to spend her time reading anything else.
stanza: Swera reads every book that she should read (according to the list).
translation:
Swera akásomá óbuli kitábu ekyóbakábuga ambú ínásóma (eríkwamaná n’elíste)
Swera a-ka-som-a obuli kitabu e-kyo-ba-ka-bug-a ambu i-na-som-a (e-ri-kwamana na e-liste)
Swera Sm.c1-TM-read-FV every c7.book AUG-c7.REL-SM.c2-TM-say-FV C C-SM.c1-read-FV (AUG-c5-according.to PREP AUG-c9.list)
"Swera reads every book that they say that she read (according to the list)."

context_07: Last week, Kabunga was ready to return from Goma to Butembo. Unfortunately, the bus had broken down at that point, and so Kabunga had to hire someone to drive him to Butembo.
stanza: Kabunga had to take a car to Butembo.
phil: No
follow-up_question: Would that sentence be ok if Kabunga couldn’t find someone to drive him? For example even though taking a car was the way he needed to get to Butembo, he wound up stuck in Goma and couldn’t go to Butembo at all. Is the sentence still ok in that sort of situation?

context_05: You are shopping for books for school, and one of the workers at the bookstore is helping you find the books you need. As you are walking past a shelf of books, the worker picks up a book and explains that it frequently sells out, so if it’s one of the books you are supposed to read, you should buy it today while they still have stock. You could probably get by in the class without it, but you’re more likely to do well if you have this book.
stanza:
wamábyá íwanganásóm’ekitábw’ ekí ky’ekalhási, kúmbé íwakígúlá munábwíre
u-a-ma-bi-a i-u-anga-na-som-a e-kitabu eki kyo ekalhasi, kumbe i-u-a-ki-gul-a munabwire
SM.2sg-TM-TM-be-FV C-SM.2sg-MOD-TM-read-FV AUG-c7.kitabu c7.this PREP class, better.that C-SM.2sg-TM-Om.c7-buy-FV today
"if you should read this book for school, you should buy it today"

Phil: OK

context_11: Masika doesn’t like swimming, but for gym class, the teacher says that she should swim today for exercise, because it would be good for her.
stanza: omugalímu mwábúyíre ati Másiká anganátsíga (the teacher says that Masika ought to swim today)
phil:
OK. However, note the tone. The sentence here will end with a mid tone.
                 omugalímu mwábúyíre ati Másiká anganátsígA.   (here the last vowel has a mid tone)

context_10: You and Masika are working on a class plan for assigning books to students. The students all have different reading levels, so you’re trying to make sure that you assign the books properly to each student according to the ability. Masika tentatively puts down a book for Kabunga, but you think it’s too advanced for him to read at this point, so you say:
stanza: Kabunga can’t read this book, we have to assign it to someone else.
translation: Kábunga syályábyá w’erisom’ekitábw’eki. Tunapásw’eríkíhá wundi múndu.

metadata.Context,04: Kambere is telling you about how long his drive to work was, and how bad the traffic was. You eventually find out that he took one of the longest and busiest roads to the office, and he could’ve taken a much shorter, less traffic-filled path. You say

stanza: You shouldn’t have taken that road, there is a shorter way to get here.
translate:
Síwabyá mundú w’ erímy’ enzir’ eyô. Hané akathirísa ako mundú akímaya erigendáyô.
Si-u-a-bi-a mundu wa e-ri-mi-a enzira eyo. Hane akathirisa ako mundu a-ki-ma-y-a e-ri-gend-a-yo
NEG-SM.2sg-TM-be-FV c1.person c1.ASSOC c5-c5-take-FV c9.road that. There.is shortcut c12-REL? c1.person SM.c1-TM-TM-go-FV c5-c5-go-FV-c9.PRN
"You shouldn't have taken that road. There is a shortcut that you could have taken."

(akathirísa = shortcut)

context_06: Two weeks ago, Kabunga needed to get from Butembo to Goma so that he could greet a friend of his. For a few days when he was planning, Kabunga wasn’t sure whether he would make it to the bus station on time after his other errands, but he manages to catch his bus to Goma.
stanza: Kabunga was able to take a bus to Goma.
translation:
Kábunga mwásálíré ín’ímya ebísí y’eGómâ
Kabunga mo-a-sal-ire i-na i-my-a e-bisi ya e-Goma
Kabunga TM-SM.c1-climb-PFV C-take-FV c9-bus go c24-Goma
"Kabunga took a bus to Goma"
follow-up_questions:
Would that sentence be acceptable in a context where Kabunga was able to take the bus (he had the time and money for it), but he decides to drive there instead?
Phil: No. 

And what about if he decides to stay at home and not go to Goma after all?
Phil: No

context_12: We pass by Kambere’s house and see that his light is on. That might mean that he’s at home (Kámbére anganáby’ékâ), but sometimes he’s forgetful and leaves his light on, so we’re not sure. As we get closer to his house, we also hear voices coming from inside the house. We can’t identify that it’s Kambere’s voice for sure, but it seems all the more likely that he is at home. So I say:
stanza: (Since we hear voices from inside the house,) now it’s more likely that Kambere is at home.
translation:
(kundi tunámów’emírengé y’omonyúmbá), mbíno léro Kámbére akándibyá ínian’ékâ
kundi tu-na-mow-a e-mi-renge ya o-mo-nyumba, mbino lero Kambere a-ka-ndi-bi-a i-ni-a-ne eka
because SM.1pl-TM-hear-FV AUG-c4-voice ASSOC AUG-c18-house maybe this.time Kambere SM.c1-TM-TM-be-FV C-COP-Sm.c1?-LOC home
"Because we are hearing voices in the house), maybe at-least-for-this-time Kambere will be that he is at home."

context_12: When Kambere attended school, the teachers tried to make him read all the time, even though he didn’t like it. Mostly he avoided reading anything, and just tried to get through school without reading any of the books he was supposed to. He finally finished school this year, and now he doesn’t have to read books anymore, he can do what he likes. He’s very happy about this (for now).
stanza: esáhá ábya omo kalhásí, Kámbére ábyá inanganásoma
phil: esáhá ábya omo kalhásí, Kámbére ábyá inanganáyírá ínásóma

context_06: Kambere is asking you for advice on how to be successful in life. You’re not sure this is such a fantastic goal to have, and that maybe he should focus on doing good for others, even if that’s at the cost of his own success. But he insists he wants to be a successful person, so you tell him:

#wamábug’uti kúmbé íwabya mundu omo-maísha wawú, wángayitsing’okomubíri
u-a-ma-bug-a u-ti kumbe i-u-a-bi-a mundu omo-maisha wawu, u-anga-yitsing-a o-ko-mubiri

Intended: "if you want to succeed, you should work hard"

context_07: Kambere is hosting a potluck party, and putting very unreasonable demands on who should bring what dish. For example, he insists that Swera has to cook and bring ekihembe, and she doesn’t even like making that dish. You try to tell Kambere that he’s being unreasonable, and say on behalf of Swera:
stanza: Swera doesn’t have to cook ekihembe, she can cook whatever she likes.
translation: Síbabúyír’ambu mupáka Swerá átanétáhuk’ekihémbê. Anganáhuka ebyályá ni byályâ.

Kambere si-a-li-a-bi-a wa e-ri-som-a lino, a-liye a-ki-sig-a i-na-hik-a oko-lubo lu-a e-ri-bi-a a-ka-som-a

context_04:
Some celebrities published a list of “1,000 books that everyone should read before they die”. Since then, Swera has been reading the books on that list, and only those books. She intends to read every single book on that list whenever she can get her hands on a copy, but she refuses to spend her time reading anything else.

context_18: Kabunga has been sick and stuck at home for weeks. As a result, he hasn’t been able to go visit friends or do anything fun. Now he’s feeling a little better, and he can leave the house once in a while, but not very often.
stanza: Kabunga is now more able to go visit his friends.
translation:
Kábunga ámâbításyábya mundú w’ eriyában’ ábira b’ iwe
Kabunga a-ma-bi-ta-sya-bi-a mundu wa e-ri-ya-ban-a a-bira ba iwe
Kabunga SM.c1-TM-TM-TM-TM-be-FV c1.person c1.ASSOC AUG-c5-go-visit-FV AUG-c2.friend c2.ASSOC his
"Kabunga has become again a person to go and visit his friends"

Kábunga ámásalá w’ erításyábyá w’ eriyátsangá n’ ábira b’ iwe
Kabunga a-ma-sal-a wa e-ri-ta-sya-bi-a wa e-ri-ya-tsang-a na a-bira ba iwe
Kabunga SM.c1-TM-vomit-FV c1.ASSOC AUG-c5-TM-TM-be-FV c1.ASSOC AUG-c5-go-play-FV with AUG-c2.friend c2.ASSOC his
"Kabunga has now become able to go and play with his friends."
consultant_note: Note that erísála literally means to vomit. But it is used as an auxiliary in Kinande.

stanza: Kambere is taller than Kabunga.

sentence_09: It is better for you to go school than for you to sleep late.
translation:
Lítóleré íwagenda oko kalhásí ómwanyá w’erisib’omongingó íwunágótsere
li-tolere i-u-a-gend-a oko kalhasi o-mu-anya wa e-ri-si-bi-a omo-ngingo i-u-na-gotsere
c5-fit C-SM.3sg-TM-go-FV LNK class AUG-c1-instead ASSOC AUG-c5-TM-be-FV AUG-c18-bed C-SM.2sg-TM-sleep
"It is better that you go to school instead of staying in bed while you are sleeping."

Ókw’iwé, ryowéne okw’igenda oko kalhásí kúlaba erisib’omongingó íwunágotsere
Oku-iwe, ri-owene oku-i-gend-a oko kalhasi ku-laba e-ri-sib-a omo-gingo i-u-na-gotsere
LNK-2sg, c5-good LNK.2sg-c5-go-FV LNK class c15-pass AUG-c5-spend.much.time c24-bed C-SM.2sg-TM-sleep
"For you, it is better to go go to school more than to stay in bed sleeping."
consultant_note: kúlaba means more. It is probably the verb erílába ‘to pass’. Kúlaba is probably a vestige  of the use of ku- as the verb class prefix in other Bantu languages. Kinande has eri- and not ku- (erílába to pass  = kupíta (in Swahili))

context_19: We’ve been in dry weather for months, and the weatherman for a while has said there’s no chance of rain anytime soon. contex_9: Swera is sick, and Kabunga is very worried. He calls the clinic and describes her symptoms to the doctor, who says that he should see her today, because she might be much worse tomorrow. So you advise Kabunga:
stanza:
If the doctor should see Swera today, go to the clinic right away.

context_09: As a group, you are working out who will bring which dish to a party. Swera isn’t here for this planning meeting, but she said that you could assign her whichever dish you think best, so long as it’s one she can actually cook. Kambere suggests that maybe Swera should bring the ekihembe, but you know she can’t cook ekihembe, so that’s a bad idea. You say…
stanza: Swera can’t cook the ekihembe, she will have to cook something else.
translation: Swera syási eríhuk’ekihémbê. Álwe mundú w’eríhuk’ékindi kíndu

context_08: You and Masika came up with a class plan for which student should read which book. After talking it over, she wrote out the class reading assignments. When you look over the list, you see that she accidentally assigned Swera’s book to Kabunga. You correct her, saying:
stanza: Kabunga doesn’t have to read this book, Swera is the one who has to read it.
translation:
Kábunga siyómundú w’erisom’ekitábw’eki. Swera yo mundú oyúnapásw’erikisóma

...Swera yo mundú w’erikisóma
